detail.abstract: Item nonresponse is a common issue in surveys. We implement an experiment to reduce nonresponse to income questions in an international household survey, looking at four different countries. Survey respondents are asked to report their exact household income. We randomize those who refuse to answer into two groups. In a follow-up question, the control group is asked to choose their income from a very granular list of brackets, the treatment group receives only three options to choose from. In all four countries, the treatment leads to a significant decrease in nonresponse. Thus, when condensed income data are sufficient, fewer answer options are a cost-effective way to reduce nonresponse.

title: A comprehensive review of regional innovation policy research: policy paradigms, evolution and underexplored topics
affiliations: Universidad Nacional de Río Negro and Universidad Nacional de Río Negro

detail.title: A comprehensive review of regional innovation policy research: policy paradigms, evolution and underexplored topics
detail.abstract: Although regional innovation policy (RIP) has gained relevance in recent decades, the literature still lacks a comprehensive review. Beyond addressing this gap, the article challenges several limitations and interpretations of previous studies. First, RIP constitutes a substantial and coherent field, rather than a subtype of (national) innovation policies. Second, RIP extends beyond the commonly reviewed studies on regional innovation systems (RIS) and smart specialization strategies (S3), encompassing other underexplored issues. Third, RIP topics are framed across all three innovation policy paradigms, not just within the innovation systems tradition. Fourth, besides distinguishing long-term and emerging topics, our analysis reveals four phases in RIS evolution (including the latest challenge-oriented turn) and rejects that S3 derives from RIS. Finally, the article highlights remaining gaps and future research and policy agendas.

title: Schrödinger's Sparsity in the Cross Section of Stock Returns
affiliations: Reichman University - Interdisciplinary Center (IDC) Herzliyah, City University of Hong Kong (CityU), City University of Hong Kong (CityU) and City University of Hong Kong (CityU)

detail.title: Schrödinger's Sparsity in the Cross Section of Stock Returns
detail.abstract: This paper proposes Schrödinger's Sparsity, a Bayesian asset pricing framework that treats sparsity as a latent feature to be inferred rather than imposed. Departing from conventional models that assume either sparse or dense structures ex ante, our approach learns the probability of sparsity in both mispricing (alphas) and factor loadings (betas) directly from the data. Empirically, we find that alphas are considerably sparser than betas, and that sparsity varies systematically with asset complexity, pricing difficulty, and macroeconomic conditions. By allowing model complexity to emerge endogenously, our method yields interpretable, adaptive, and high-performing predictions, offering a principled bridge between sparse selection and dense shrinkage approaches.

title: The Early Public-Private Challenge of Commercializing Orbital Space: Comsat-Intelsat and Matters of Concern
affiliations: SUNY Polytechnic Institute and OREGON HEALTH & SCIENCE UNIVERSITY

detail.title: The Early Public-Private Challenge of Commercializing Orbital Space: Comsat-Intelsat and Matters of Concern

declarations.funderStatement: This research received generous support from the Sustainable Aerospace Energy Center at the State University of New York Polytechnic Institute and the College of Business, Center for Business and Applied Ethics.

detail.abstract: This study investigates the early commercialization of orbital space through a sociotechnical case analysis of the Comsat-Intelsat Network (CIN)-the first and only publicprivate enterprise (PPE) implemented in outer space. Drawing on the Matters of Concern (MCs) framework, it identifies and analyzes four core sociotechnical controversies that shaped CIN's trajectory: commercialization, stabilization, prognostication, and systematization. The research highlights how CIN's PPE model balanced government oversight with private innovation under conditions of low technological readiness, geopolitical tension, and systemic uncertainty. The findings reveal that successful PPEs require adaptive governance, inclusive stakeholder coordination, and pragmatic foresight. By extrapolating lessons from CIN, the study proposes a forward-looking framework for structuring PPEs in cislunar and interplanetary development, offering new insights for managing complexity in the next phase of space commercialization.

title: Bridging Epistemologies: Integrating Faith into STEM Education and Its Impact on Student Learning Outcomes
affiliations: African Leadership University, Open Christian University and African Leadership University

detail.title: Bridging Epistemologies: Integrating Faith into STEM Education and Its Impact on Student Learning Outcomes
detail.abstract: Background: Global STEM reforms increasingly privilege technical proficiency while sidelining moral teleology, leaving graduates adept with code but adrift on questions of purpose. This study advances a Scripture-anchored, interdisciplinary framework that reunites scientific inquiry with a Christian worldview and empirically tests its influence on student learning. Methodology: Adopting a qualitative-dominant mixed-methods design, we executed an AI-assisted meta-synthesis of 180 peer-reviewed sources (2019-2025) and triangulated those insights with multi-site case studies of Wheaton College (USA), Daystar University (Kenya), and Redeemer University (Canada). Data-curricula, alumni surveys, and classroom artefacts-underwent thematic coding and cross-case pattern matching, generating testable propositions linking faith-based instruction, epistemic coherence, and learning outcomes. Results: Across contexts, faith-integrated STEM programmes exhibited markedly greater cognitive engagement, deeper ethical reasoning, and heightened spiritual formation than secular comparators. Meta-synthesised effect sizes (Hedges g = 0.35-0.55) show that explicit biblical framing elevates moral-reasoning and purpose metrics, with the most pronounced gains among students previously unfamiliar with faith-learning integration. Key mediators include faculty integration skill, mission-aligned accreditation standards, and culturally attuned pedagogy. Conclusions: Positioning sola Scriptura as the ultimate epistemic authority does not dilute scientific rigour; it re-humanises STEM by welding empirical facts to transcendent purpose. The proposed framework supplies educators, policymakers, and accreditation bodies with a scalable roadmap for producing technically competent, ethically resilient graduates equipped to steward AI, biotechnology, and green-tech frontiers. Future research should deploy longitudinal, multi-institutional designs and neurocognitive measures to further validate the model's causal pathways and global applicability.

title: The overlapping model of earnings, cash flows, and accruals
affiliations: University of Denver and University of Denver - School of Accountancy

detail.title: The overlapping model of earnings, cash flows, and accruals
detail.abstract: We challenge a pervasive assumption in financial accounting research that cash flows and accruals are mutually exclusive components of earnings (the "earnings component model") and introduce an alternative model of earnings, cash flows, and accruals based on the observation that earnings and cash flows are partially overlapping summary measures of firm performance (the "overlapping model"). Rather than splitting earnings into cash flows and accruals, the overlapping model splits earnings and cash flows into "overlaps" (cash transactions included in earnings) and two types of accruals: (1) "inclusions" (non-cash transactions included in earnings) and (2) "exclusions" (cash transactions excluded from earnings). We demonstrate that the two models may produce contradictory inferences on the Financial Accounting Standards Board's (FASB) assertion that earnings are more informative than cash flows about future cash flows. Our findings illustrate the importance of separately considering overlaps, inclusions, and exclusions when comparing the informativeness of earnings and cash flows. Data Availability: All data are available from the public sources cited in the text.

title: When is Less More? Bank Arrangements for Liquidity vs Central Bank Support *
affiliations: University of Chicago - Booth School of Business, New York University (NYU) - New York University and New York University (NYU)

detail.title: When is Less More? Bank Arrangements for Liquidity vs Central Bank Support *
detail.abstract: Theory suggests that in the face of fire-sale externalities, banks have incentives to overinvest in order to issue excessive money-like deposit liabilities. The existence of a private market for insurance such as contingent capital can eliminate the overinvestment incentives, leading to efficient outcomes. However, it does not eliminate fire sales. A central bank that can infuse liquidity cheaply may be motivated to intervene in the face of fire sales. If so, it can crowd out the private market and, if liquidity intervention is not priced at higher-than-breakeven rates, induce overinvestment. We examine various forms of public intervention to identify the least distortionary ones. Our analysis helps understand the historical prevalence of private insurance in the era preceding central banks and deposit insurance, their subsequent disappearance, as well as the continuing incidence of banking crises and speculative excesses. * We are grateful to Agustin Carstens, Anastasios Dosis, Kristin Forbes (discussant), Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas (discussant)

title: Financial Risk and Investment in Artificial Intelligence in the USA: A Fresh Evidence from Quantile Wavelet Regression and Quantile Wavelet Correlation Tests
affiliations: European University of Lefke - Department of Banking and Finance, Holy Spirit University of Kaslik (USEK), European University of Lefke and Qingdao University

detail.title: Financial Risk and Investment in Artificial Intelligence in the USA: A Fresh Evidence from Quantile Wavelet Regression and Quantile Wavelet Correlation Tests
detail.abstract: The present study aims to capture the co-movement between financial risk and Investment in Artificial Intelligence in the USA using novel approaches, which are Quantile in ADF Unit Root, Quantile Wavelet Regression, and Wavelet Quantile Correlation Tests. The outcomes clearly reveal that financial stability and investment in artificial intelligence in the USA are positively correlated at different quantiles and time-periods.

title: THE EVOLUTION OF LEGAL KNOWLEDGE WORK IN AN AGE OF BRILLIANT(?) TECHNOLOGIES: FROM ROBO-LAWYER TO DIGITAL LAW CLERK
affiliations: University of Melbourne - Melbourne Law School and University of Melbourne - Law School

detail.title: THE EVOLUTION OF LEGAL KNOWLEDGE WORK IN AN AGE OF BRILLIANT(?) TECHNOLOGIES: FROM ROBO-LAWYER TO DIGITAL LAW CLERK
detail.abstract: Generative AI (genAI) is being hailed by legal technology insiders and many in the profession as a major disruptive force within the legal practice ecosystem. Unlike earlier forms of digital innovation, genAI has the potential to support and possibly take over at least some of the diagnostic and analytical functions performed by human lawyers. It thus adds a new dimension to the debate over how (and how much) AI will be a substitutive technology, displacing humans from knowledge work, and how it might serve to augment and enhance human expertise in performing knowledge roles. At present, however, we have relatively little objective understanding of how it is being used and the scale of its impact on what lawyers in Australia actually do. This paper takes a two-pronged approach to this question. First, we explore the potential and prospective impact of emerging AI technologies through a new taxonomy of four ideal types (archetypes) that seek to capture different, emergent, substitutive and augmentative patterns of AI-enabled legal knowledge work. Secondly, we examine the current impact of genAI on legal work from three perspectives: the limited data on its current deployment in Australia; an analysis of the nature of legal competence, and activity analysis drawing on empirical studies of lawyers' use of time. On the basis of this analysis, we argue that, by virtue of a mix of cultural, economic, and technical constraints, genAI is both unevenly distributed across the legal ecosystem, and currently over-hyped, operating chiefly as a kind of 'digital law clerk', substituting for and augmenting human work on only a limited range of lower level diagnostic tasks. Looking to the future, our analysis indicates that whether genAI and later AI iterations can become more broadly augmentative and transformative of the legal function, will depend on the technology's capacity to move safely through our more complex archetypes, taking on more sophisticated analytical and inferential tasks, and demonstrating a wider range of skills that reflect the more human qualities of lawyering. If it can do this, then our archetypal change model suggests the profession might yet be on the cusp of a period of significant adaptation not just to its legal work practices, but to the law business model and perhaps even underlying professional identity constructs. We conclude by identifying some directions for future research suggested by this analysis.

title: Achieving Sustainable Development Goals： a Perspective on Urban Climate Policy in China
affiliations: Capital University of Economics and Business, Capital University of Economics and Business, Capital University of Economics and Business and Capital University of Economics and Business

detail.title: Achieving Sustainable Development Goals： a Perspective on Urban Climate Policy in China

keywords: Evolutionary Game model. PSOAG Clustering Early warning system

detail.abstract: Fostering urban sustainable development within the climate policy is an important topic in China. In this paper, an evolutionary game theory is constructed to analyze the strategic interactions between city governments regarding the adoption of climate policies, integrating both synergistic and spillover effects across categories. And a structural equation model (SEM) is utilised to elucidate the mediating mechanisms of innovation and green efficiency on the transmission pathways from climate policy to sustainability results. Empirical findings suggest that punitive climate policies, such as environmental taxes or emission charges, are positively associated with improvements in green innovation and green efficiency, thereby advancing sustainable development. If innovation can effectively converts into increased green efficiency, supportive climate policies, such as fiscal incentives and subsidies, are more efficacious in fostering innovation, which can further augment sustainability either directly or indirectly. However, subsidies may lead to rent-seeking behavior or resource misallocation, failing to stimulate innovation and potentially undermining sustainability outcomes. Specifically, in eastern cities or leading cities with higher levels of sustainability, punitive climate policies are more effective at improving green innovation, while supportive policies are better suited to promote general innovation. Conversely, in western or lagging cities, punitive policies may suppress innovation due to limited absorptive capacity, and supportive policies fail to deliver meaningful improvements in green efficiency. These findings underscore the need for context-specific policy design and differentiated adjustments. Furthermore, for cities identified by the early warning system as being at risk of sustainability, climate policies should be promptly recalibrated.

title: Analysis symbolic of the Executive Branch from cultural legitimacy in Colombia Executive Branch, Culture and Legitimacy
affiliations: EDUKIVOTOS

detail.title: Analysis symbolic of the Executive Branch from cultural legitimacy in Colombia Executive Branch, Culture and Legitimacy
detail.abstract: This article carries out a cultural and sociological analysis of Title VII-"On the Executive Branch"-of the 1991 Colombian Political Constitution, using Émile Durkheim's notion of moral cohesion and the philosophy of legal positivism as theoretical bases. It studies whether the institutional design of the executive branch corresponds to the principles established in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR), especially in relation to access to public administration, accountability, and legal equality. Furthermore, it examines whether the articles that comprise this title are consistent with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), emphasizing SDG 10 (reduction of inequalities), SDG 16 (strong institutions), and SDG 17 (partnerships for development). From a symbolic and territorial reading, gaps in citizen appropriation of executive institutionality are identified, and a reinterpretation of its legitimacy is proposed from the perspective of Colombian sociocultural diversity.

title: Technical and Calibration Challenges in the U.S. Basel III Endgame Rulemaking for Credit Risk
affiliations: INDEPENDENT RESEARCH PAPER

detail.title: Technical and Calibration Challenges in the U.S. Basel III Endgame Rulemaking for Credit Risk

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The views expressed herein—including the framing and interpretation of issues raised in the comment letters—are solely the author’s and do not represent the views of the author’s former employer or any industry association. For full disclosure, the author participated in the industry workgroups and contributed to the industry’s feedback on B3E NPR.
declarations.ethicsApproval: Not applicable
declarations.funderStatement: None

detail.abstract:
In July 2023, U.S. regulatory agencies issued a proposal for the Basel III Endgame (B3E NPR), the updated capital rules for banks. The U.S. version of B3E deviated substantially from the standards of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (BCBS) and would have increased capital requirements for large banks significantly—an industry study projected a rise of 25% to 30%. Due to the scale of the proposed increase, the NPR faced strong opposition from banks, their clients, elected officials, and public interest groups. Although the agencies announced plans to re-propose the framework to address the concerns last year, the issues raised remain unresolved today.

The Federal Reserve Board recently announced a plan for a comprehensive capital regulation reform. The resolution of the B3E proposal—arguably, the “endgame of the Endgame”—is a core part of this effort.

This article provides an in-depth yet accessible summary and analysis of feedback on the B3E NPR, focusing on credit risk weights, counterparty credit risk, and CVA. These issues are critical to the corporate lending and financial market businesses of large banks. While certain headline concerns have garnered significant media and academic attention, many other crucial topics remain inaccessible to a broader audience due to their complexity and the extensive technical details spread across hundreds of pages.

The resolution of the issues from two years ago is critical to a successful rulemaking since it will shape the formation of the most important building blocks of B3E—capital treatments for loans, derivatives, and securities financing transactions (SFTs). This article aims to help interested readers understand the issues and their impacts using simple language. Some of the topics discussed stem from deliberate policy decisions to raise capital to a desired level, while others are “unintentional but consequential,” reflecting material unintended consequences of either purposeful supervisory choices or inadvertent drafting issues.

title: When Big is Slow: Tax-motivated Income Shifting and Dividend Payouts of Korean Chaebols after the Transition to a Territorial Tax System
affiliations: Kookmin University

detail.title: When Big is Slow: Tax-motivated Income Shifting and Dividend Payouts of Korean Chaebols after the Transition to a Territorial Tax System
detail.abstract: This study examines how the organizational characteristics of chaebols affect the agility of taxplanning decision-making. Using the transition from a worldwide to territorial tax system in South Korea in 2023 as a quasi-exogenous shock, the analysis shows that multinational corporations (MNCs) significantly increased tax-motivated income shifting and dividend payouts following the reform. However, among MNCs, chaebol firms were less responsive than non-chaebol firms. The results suggest that the complex and hierarchical organizational structures of chaebols hinder swift strategic adjustments in response to tax-policy changes. This study expands and diversifies the literature on the organizational characteristics of chaebols by presenting empirical evidence challenging prior findings that chaebols are always more aggressive than non-chaebols in tax avoidance.

title: DEVISE : Depth-Aware Vegetation Indexing System
affiliations: University of Rochester, University of Rochester, University of Rochester, University of Rochester and University of Rochester

detail.title: DEVISE : Depth-Aware Vegetation Indexing System
detail.abstract: Urban greenness is most meaningful at the pedestrian scale, yet most current metrics rely on coarse satellite imagery or street-view indices that ignore depth. We introduce DEVISE-the Depth-Aware Vegetation Indexing System-an endto-end pipeline that combines Mask2Former panoptic segmentation, MiDaS monocular depth estimation, and HSV filtering to compute distance-weighted canopy, grass, and understory shares from Google Street View (GSV) images. Applied to 1,441,746 panoramas collected every 20 m along the road networks of 60 U.S. swing counties (2004-2024), DEVISE produces the first county-month panel of street-level greenness spanning two decades. DEVISE improves on prior approaches in three key respects. First, relative to the Panorama-View Green View Index (PVGVI) of Zhang et al. (2023), it replaces a CNN backbone with a transformer, introduces depth weighting, and disaggregates vegetation classes, thereby eliminating far-field bias and reducing color-based false positives. Second, compared with the scalable Green View Index framework of Xia et al. (2021), DEVISE restores semantic precision in cluttered scenes and reduces over-estimation by pairing depth cues with spectral post-processing. Third, unlike the tree-species detector of Choi and Lee (2022), which is accurate but computationally demanding, DEVISE prioritizes longitudinal scalability, processing the national panel in six months of cloud compute while preserving perceptual realism. This study also offers a quantitative demonstration of DEVISE 's capabilities. Regression analyses show that a one-percentage-point increase in the most recent Democratic presidential vote share is linked to a 0.52-0.71 percentage-point gain in depth-adjusted total greenness after controlling for climate and socioeconomic covariates; this association remains robust with county and month fixed effects (R 2 ≈ 0.91-0.99). These findings imply that partisan alignment translates into observable street-level environmental benefits, highlighting the political significance of urban forestry. To facilitate replication and extension, all code, trained weights, and a commandline interface will be released as the open-source devise Python package. By integrating transformer segmentation, depth-aware weighting, and rigorous social science validation, DEVISE establishes a new benchmark for scalable, policy-ready audits of perceptual equity in urban environments.

title: The Tax on Hope: Why GST's 'Actionable Claim as a Good' Fiction is a Legal Absurdity
affiliations: GSTbyMM

detail.title: The Tax on Hope: Why GST's 'Actionable Claim as a Good' Fiction is a Legal Absurdity

keywords: H. Anraj v. Government of Tamil Nadu

detail.abstract:
The Goods and Services Tax (GST) regime’s treatment of specified actionable claims—lottery, betting, horse racing, casinos, and online money gaming—presents a significant doctrinal and constitutional anomaly. While the law generally excludes actionable claims from the tax net, it carves out these specific categories, classifying them as taxable “goods.” This paper argues that the central flaw in this approach is not merely one of discriminatory treatment under Article 14, but a more fundamental error in classification.

Our central thesis is that the law irrationally bifurcates economically identical transactions—services that create a contingent right—by mistaking the customer’s desire (the hope for a prize) for the operator’s supply (the performance of a service).

Through a comparative analysis with non-contentious parallels such as insurance policies and extended warranties, the paper establishes that the consistent legal principle is to tax the underlying supply of a service, not the consequential actionable claim. It then deconstructs the supplies in the specified categories, concluding they are, in substance, services of participation, entertainment, and management.

We further demonstrate that this misclassification renders the legal fiction of an “actionable claim as a good” entirely redundant, as the GST framework is already equipped to tax the revenue from these underlying services. Ultimately, we conclude that this forced classification is not only doctrinally incoherent and textually superfluous but also constitutionally suspect, straining the definition of “goods” under Article 366(12). It creates a contorted legal landscape that requires judicial reconsideration to restore logical consistency and constitutional alignment to India’s indirect tax law.

title: Analysis of Dropouts from IITs and Central Institutions
affiliations: Central University of Jammu

detail.title: Analysis of Dropouts from IITs and Central Institutions
detail.abstract: This article investigates the alarming dropout rates of students from Scheduled Caste (SC), Scheduled Tribe (ST), and Other Backward Classes (OBC) in India's premier higher education institutions, including IITs, IIMs, and Central Universities. Framed against a backdrop of historical and ongoing caste-based oppression, the analysis posits that these dropouts are not isolated failures but symptoms of pervasive "social toxicity" and systemic marginalization that impacts individuals from prenatal stages to posthumous rites. The study aims to critically deconstruct the conventional narrative that attributes these dropouts primarily to financial constraints or individual academic shortcomings, arguing that such explanations are often a "policy polemic" that obscures the more profound challenges of caste-based discrimination, social alienation, and a non-inclusive institutional climate. Employing a multifaceted approach, the article synthesizes quantitative data on dropout rates and entrance examination performance with qualitative analysis of case studies, institutional practices, and policy critiques. Key findings reveal that over 13,600 reserved category students dropped out between 2018 and 2023. Analysis of JEE and CAT entrance scores demonstrates that while performance gaps persist, they are often narrower than portrayed and are decreasing, challenging the simplistic narrative of "lack of merit." The paper identifies the primary drivers of attrition as systemic issues, including persistent microaggressions, social and academic isolation, inadequate and culturally insensitive support systems, and institutional apathy. Evidence is drawn from the struggles of faculty from marginalized backgrounds, discriminatory practices such as mess hall segregation, and the stark contrast between these issues and institutional priorities. The article concludes that attributing dropouts to superficial causes allows institutions to evade the necessary work of dismantling systemic barriers. It calls for a paradigm shift from focusing solely on access to ensuring retention through proactive measures, including fostering genuine inclusivity, implementing robust and empathetic support systems, and holding institutional leadership accountable for creating equitable environments where all students can thrive.

title: How Terrorism has Impacted Global Security: A Case Study of the Boko Haram Insurgents in Northern Nigeria
affiliations: Coventry University

detail.title: How Terrorism has Impacted Global Security: A Case Study of the Boko Haram Insurgents in Northern Nigeria

declarations.ethicsApproval: This study was approved by the Coventry University Ethics Committee as a high-risk project. Certificate of Ethical Approval was granted on 01 April 2021.

detail.abstract: In recent times, especially after the attack on U.S in 2001, the world has seen the destructive impact of terrorism and have brought to the world’s attention the proliferation of terrorist groups like the Boko Haram sect, since the beginning of their violent attacks in Northern Nigeria, there has been an enormous loss of lives and properties. Boko Haram that was formerly known to be a machete yielding group with no arms sophistication now poses as a threat to global security. It has been argued that Boko Haram is now more ruthless compared to AlQaeda terrorist group due to their violent activities like the kidnapping of 276 Chibok girls, the killing of both Christians and Muslims, bombing of the United Nations structure in Abuja, kidnapping and killing of foreigners in Nigeria and have even extended attacks to neighbouring countries like Chad, Cameroun and Niger. An extensive argument has been established on the level of threat that Boko Haram poses to global security. Though some persons see Boko Haram as a regional threat, others regard it as an existential threat to the society particularly global security. In order to foster global security in the international scene, multilateral organisations were created with a collective agreement to aid with global issues and security with organisations like the U.N, however, these organisations have failed to help Nigeria to completely end Boko Haram violent activities in Nigeria. The realism theory helps to explain why idealism has failed to curb out terrorism in the international arena, this is due to the selfish nature of the international system. Boko Haram has adversely impacted Nigeria and global security, the global community ought to come together to end Boko Haram’s violent activities and possibly end terrorism altogether to foster global security.

title: Talking Green: The Impact of Climate-Related ECB Announcements on Green Bond Markets
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Talking Green: The Impact of Climate-Related ECB Announcements on Green Bond Markets
detail.abstract: This paper analyzes the impact of climate-related ECB communication on green bond returns. Green bonds play a crucial role in financing the transition to a carbon-neutral economy, and while the ECB cannot directly finance sustainable projects, its strategy and communication are key tools to influence market expectations. Using an event study combined with Structural Topic Modeling (STM), we examine 40 climate-related ECB announcements between 2019 and 2023. Our results show that green bond returns respond to these announcements, with significant variation in both direction and magnitude. The STM analysis further reveals that Green finance and Climate-related risk topics are associated with the most pronounced negative abnormal returns, while Sustainable growth topics cause modest positive responses. The findings underscore the importance of clear and well-targeted communication to avoid unintended market volatility and support the broader green transition.

title: Discussions on Public Relations and Marketing: Trends in Spanish University Degrees. Estudio comparativo con Portugal, Estados Unidos y Gran Bretaña)

detail.title: Discussions on Public Relations and Marketing: Trends in Spanish University Degrees. Comparative Study on Portugal, the US and the UK (Las relaciones públicas y el marketing: tendencias en los grados de las universidades españolas. Estudio comparativo con Portugal, Estados Unidos y Gran Bretaña)

publicationDetails.detailsText: Revista Internacional de Relaciones Públicas, volume 10, issue 19, 2020[10.5783/RIRP-19-2020-09-157-178]

detail.abstract: English Abstract: The following is a reflection on Spanish undergraduate studies that combine the concepts of marketing and public relations. Sharing origins and often functions and specialists, both concepts have run parallel paths that have merged on multiple occasions. This evolution has been studied from different points of view. Initially, marketing experts included PR techniques as an additional tool to grant it a greater specific instrumental relevance over time. On the other hand, PR scholars have tried to dissociate themselves from marketing in order acquire an independent position within the field of communication. In Spain, these conceptual differences are currently blurred due to the creation of new university degrees and double degrees combining both disciplines. This trend is evidenced within the Spanish university market which, throughout this article, will be compared to other markets, namely the American and the British ones, as a scientific reference for both concepts, and to the Portuguese one, given its geographical proximity. We will reflect on the reasons that have led the Spanish university market to combine both concepts and to offer official studies that include them in their nomenclature, far from the historical tradition in this country, where studies in public relations have been related to the  field of communication, while those in marketing have been related to the field of economics. The identification of this trend in the job market of organisational communication professionals poses new challenges to training institutions, especially to universities. Spanish Abstract: Presentamos una reflexión sobre los estudios universitarios españoles que combinan los conceptos de marketing y relaciones públicas. Compartiendo orígenes y a menudo funciones y especialistas, ambos conceptos han recorrido caminos paralelos que se han fusionado en múltiples ocasiones. Esta evolución ha sido estudiada desde diferentes puntos de vista. Inicialmente, los expertos en marketing incluyeron las técnicas de relaciones públicas como una herramienta propia, pero éstas fueron alcanzando una mayor relevancia a lo largo del tiempo. Por otro lado, los estudiosos de las relaciones públicas han tratado de disociarse del marketing para adquirir una posición independiente dentro del campo de la comunicación. En España, estas diferencias conceptuales están actualmente desdibujadas debido a la creación de nuevos títulos universitarios y dobles títulos que combinan ambas disciplinas. Esta tendencia se evidencia en el mercado universitario español que, a lo largo de este artículo, se comparará con otros mercados: el americano y el británico, como referencia científica para ambos conceptos, y con el portugués, dada su proximidad geográfica. Reflexionaremos sobre las razones que han llevado al mercado universitario español a conjugar ambos conceptos y a ofrecer estudios oficiales que los incluyan en su nomenclatura, lejos de la tradición histórica de este país, donde los estudios de relaciones públicas han estado relacionados con el campo de la comunicación, mientras que los de marketing han estado relacionados con el campo de la economía. La identificación de esta tendencia en el mercado laboral de los profesionales de la comunicación organizativa plantea nuevos retos a las instituciones de formación, especialmente a las universidades.)

title: Trap Door: The Underappreciated Effect of Complexity on Decisions
affiliations: University of Illinois Chicago and Rutgers University-Camden

detail.title: Trap Door: The Underappreciated Effect of Complexity on Decisions
detail.abstract: In deciding among options involving uncertainty, the rational decision maker will calculate the expected utility of the options and select the one with the largest value. However, in some settings, expected utility is impossible to calculate. For example, when there are numerous states of the world and the probabilities of these states are difficult (or impossible) to learn. The effects of this complexity on decision making are often overlooked and we refer to the effect as the Trap Door. We note Trap Door effects in the decision to wash one’s hands and in the decision regarding anti-cholesterol drugs. There are likely several other settings where the failure to account for the complexity that renders expected utility impossible to calculate has significant consequences.

title: Preference Robust Insurance Design
affiliations: Shanghai University of Finance and Economics and Southern University of Science and Technology

detail.title: Preference Robust Insurance Design
detail.abstract: This paper studies the problem of preference robust insurance design within the risk minimization framework and from a decision maker's (DM's) perspective. We focus on the case that the DM's risk preference is not completely known and would consider all the distortion functions that meet some criteria, such as preferring certain lotteries over other lotteries and having some confidence intervals for the risks of a list of lotteries when making decision. Under the expectedvalue premium principle, the DM picks the robust insurance indemnity function that minimizes its risk exposure based on the worst-case distortion risk measure. By assuming that the DM's risk preferences have certain curvature, such as being concave or inverse S-shaped, we disentangle the structure of the optimal indemnity function and the worst-case distortion function in an analytical way, and give the tractable reformulations to determine the later when the underlying loss is discretely distributed. Moreover, several extensions to our framework are presented and discussed. Some numerical examples are given at the end to show more implications of our main results.

title: Why Did the Two Koreas Diverge?
affiliations: Yeungnam University

detail.title: Why Did the Two Koreas Diverge?
detail.abstract: This study models North Korea as a Solow economy to measure the role of different causes driving the country's growth underperformance visa -vis South Korea from 1958-2018. Counterfactual experiments show that North Korea's nonperformance resulted primarily from productivity failure, with the disintegration of the Soviet Union and high defense burden aggravating the decline. These findings align with the outcomes from experiments using a Ramsey model calibrated to stand for South Korea and subjected to North Korean shocks. The productivity divergence resulted primarily from the increasingly despotic North Korea's failure to shed misallocation as rapidly the democratizing South Korea did.

title: DFAS Doctrine Compendium: Philosophical, Strategic, and Systemic Frameworks for AI Governance, Crisis Intervention, and Algorithmic Control
