This paper aims to provide insights for practitioners and researchers seeking to harness the power of data analytics in optimizing maintenance strategies and supply chain performance.

title: Robust Contract with Career Concerns
affiliations: Yale University, Department of Economics and London School of Economics and Political Science

detail.title: Robust Contract with Career Concerns
detail.abstract: An employer contracts with a worker to incentivize efforts whose productivity depends on ability; the worker then enters a market that pays him contingent on ability evaluation. With non-additive monitoring technology, the interdependence between market expectations and worker efforts can lead to multiple equilibria (contrasting Holmström (1982/1999); Gibbons and Murphy (1992)). We identify a sufficient and necessary criterion for the employer to face such strategic uncertainty—one linked to skill-effort complementarity, a pervasive feature of labor markets. To fully implement work, the employer optimally creates private wage discrimination to iteratively eliminate pessimistic market expectations and low worker efforts. Our result suggests that present contractual privacy, employers' coordination motives generate within-group pay inequality. The comparative statics further explain several stylized facts about residual wage dispersion.

title: Review of Applied Science and Technology
affiliations: Western Illinois University

detail.title: Review of Applied Science and Technology
detail.abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive conceptual framework for the integration of AI-enabled Decision Support Systems (DSS) into infrastructure project management, with a focus on enhancing costefficiency, resource optimization, and multi-stakeholder coordination in U.S. public works. As infrastructure projects become increasingly complex and data-intensive, the adoption of intelligent systems capable of processing real-time information and generating actionable insights is crucial for timely and effective decision-making. The study explores the role of artificial intelligence, including machine learning, predictive analytics, and natural language processing, in conjunction with enterprise platforms such as Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP), Customer Relationship Management (CRM), and Geographic Information Systems (GIS). Through a meta-analysis of 178 empirical studies and case evidence from state and federal infrastructure programs, the paper identifies critical enablers for successful implementation, including data interoperability, explainable AI interfaces, and integration with existing digital workflows. The proposed framework emphasizes dynamic scheduling, risk forecasting, lifecycle asset management, and compliance monitoring as core functional pillars of AI-DSS in infrastructure contexts. Furthermore, the study highlights institutional and governance considerations, such as change management, algorithmic accountability, and user adoption challenges, which significantly influence system performance. This contribution aligns with broader national goals of digital transformation, transparency, and sustainability in public sector infrastructure development.

title: GraviElectroDynamics: A New Law for Controlling Effective Mass through Resonant and Spin-Enhanced Vacuum Polarization
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: GraviElectroDynamics: A New Law for Controlling Effective Mass through Resonant and Spin-Enhanced Vacuum Polarization
detail.abstract:
This paper presents a novel physical law — the Law of GraviElectroDynamics — describing the interaction between time-varying electromagnetic fields and quantum vacuum polarization. The resulting local change in vacuum energy density modifies the effective mass of an object via the equivalence principle ∆m = ∆U/c2 . The law is derived from first principles of General Relativity and Quantum Electrodynamics, making it theoretically robust. The law is given by: ∆m = η · G c 4 Z V Γ(ω) ·  ∂ 2 ∂t2  ε0E2 + µ −1 0 B2 2  dV where η incorporates spin polarization effects and Γ(ω) accounts for resonant enhancement due to plasma oscillations.

We present a new physical model—GraviElectroDynamics—that describes the influence of a time-varying electromagnetic field on the local energy density of the quantum vacuum. This leads to a change in the effective mass of an object through the equivalence of energy and mass. A mathematical formulation of the law is provided, along with an experimental setup for measuring mass changes under pulsed microwave fields. A computational model in Python was developed to simulate temporal signal behavior, estimate noise levels, and calculate the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR).

title: From Standard to Strategy: Digital Battery Passports Building Sustainability Paradigm of Global Supply Chains
affiliations: Yonsei University and Yonsei University

detail.title: From Standard to Strategy: Digital Battery Passports Building Sustainability Paradigm of Global Supply Chains
detail.abstract: This article examines the strategic implications of the EU's Battery Digital Product Passport (DBP), introduced under Regulation 2023/1542, for global electric vehicle (EV) battery supply chains, especially for latecomer firms in developing countries. The DBP requires batteries sold in the EU to be digitally traceable, reporting data on carbon footprint, sourcing, performance, and recycling. While this standard enhances transparency and supports sustainability goals for lead firms in advanced economies, it imposes significant compliance burdens on lower-tier suppliers, especially those in countries with limited digital and regulatory infrastructure. The DBP is not merely a technical requirement-it reconfigures global value chains through institutional pressure. While literature illustrates that latecomer firms face a binary choice, compliance by upgrading capabilities or risk exclusion, the country data and the case study of one EV battery maker suggest alternative strategy. While the EV battery makers and tier-1 suppliers have proactively coped with the DBP, the lower-tier suppliers and their governments were not necessarily ready for the regulation. The EV battery makers increased vertical integration, entering the raw material-rich countries, rather than strengthening business cooperation with the local suppliers. At the same time, the DBP was aligned with geopolitical shifts, such as the Inflation Reduction Act and EU industrial policy, which encourage nearshoring and friendshoring. The article concludes that without capacity-building efforts, the DBP may deepen global technological divides and marginalize local firms in least developing countries. It calls for coordinated action-regional alliances, investment in digital infrastructure, and inclusive standards development-to ensure equitable participation in the evolving battery value chain.

title: Cost Reduction and Efficiency Improvement in Manufacturing: A Comprehensive
affiliations: University of Tennessee at Martin

detail.title: Cost Reduction and Efficiency Improvement in Manufacturing: A Comprehensive
detail.abstract: This comprehensive literature review synthesizes current research and best practices on strategies for achieving cost reduction and operational efficiency within the global manufacturing sector. Facing intensifying competition, resource constraints, and sustainability imperatives, manufacturers require multifaceted approaches to optimize performance. The review traces the historical evolution from Fordist mass production through the transformative Lean revolution, highlighting the enduring importance of waste elimination (Muda) as a core principle. It critically examines the foundational tools and philosophies of Lean Manufacturing (e.g., Value Stream Mapping, JIT, Kaizen, TPM) and complementary methodologies like Six Sigma, emphasizing their role in identifying and removing non-value-added activities.

title: Comunicação e gestão de crises em empresas galegas: estudo da sua evolução nos últimos dois anos (Communication and Crisis Management in Galician Companies: Study of its Evolution in the Last Two Years)
affiliations: Universidade de Vigo, University of Vigo and Universidade de Vigo

detail.title: Comunicação e gestão de crises em empresas galegas: estudo da sua evolução nos últimos dois anos (Communication and Crisis Management in Galician Companies: Study of its Evolution in the Last Two Years)

declarations.funderStatement: This work is financed by national funds through FCT – Foundation for Science and Technology, I.P., under the project UID/CCI/00736/2019. The Strategic Project of the Center for Communication and Society Studies

detail.abstract: Portuguese Abstract: Este é um estudo no qual se explora a abordagem de comunicação de crise utilizada pelas empresas galegas classificadas como "altamente poluentes". Tendo como ponto de partida o Registro Estatal de Emisiones y Fuentes Contaminantes do Ministerio de la Transición Ecológica (PRTR Espanha), foi estabelecido o universo de estudo e analisou-se a atividade comunicativa das 87 empresas sediadas na Galiza, que possuem o maior índice de emissões poluentes (soma de resíduos e emissões do ano de 2016), através da realização de entrevistas em profundidade. Os resultados foram comparados com aqueles que foram obtidos no ano de 2014, na primeira fase do estudo, que incluiu a recolha de informações de 120 empresas. O objetivo deste trabalho foi realizar uma análise da gestão de crise destas empresas e, assim, avaliar a atividade comunicativa do setor, bem como a sua evolução nos últimos anos (2014-2016). (This study analysed the communicative approach followed by Galician companies classified as “highly polluting” in crisis situations. Taking as a starting point the Registro Estatal de Emisiones y Fuentes Contaminantes, dependent of the Ministerio de la Transición Ecológica (PRTR Spain), the universe under study has been established and the communicative activity of the 87 companies based in Galicia with the highest polluting emissions index (sum of waste and emissions, data referring to 2016) has been analysed through in-depth interviews. The results are compared with those obtained two years ago, in the first phase of the study, when information was collected from 120 companies (data from 2014). The purpose of the study is to carry out an analysis of crisis management of this companies and thus be able to assess the communication activity in this sector, as well as its evolution in recent years (2014-2016)

title: How Group Lives Go Well
affiliations: Northwestern University and Northwestern University

detail.title: How Group Lives Go Well
detail.abstract: This paper explores the ontological space of group well-being, proposing a framework for representing collective welfare, group functions, and long-term contributions within an ontology engineering context. Traditional well-being theories focus on individual states, often relying on hedonistic, desire-satisfaction, or objective list models. Such approaches struggle to account for cases where individual sacrifices contribute to broader social progress-a critical challenge in modeling group flourishing. To address this, the paper refines and extends the Counterfactual Account (CT) of well-being, which evaluates goodness of an event by comparing an individual's actual well-being with a hypothetical counterpart in a nearby possible world. While useful, this framework is insufficient for group-level ontologies, where well-being depends on functional persistence, institutional roles, and historical impact rather than immediate individual outcomes. Drawing on Basic Formal Ontology (BFO), the paper introduces a model in which group flourishing is evaluated in terms of group functional, where members bear roles and exhibit persistence conditions akin to biological systems or designed artifacts. This approach enables semantic interoperability for modeling longitudinal social contributions, allowing for structured reasoning about group welfare, social institutions, and group flourishing over time.

reference: ITS 33rd European Conference 2025 30th June – 1st July 2025, Edinburgh, UK
title: Identifying The Root Causes of Differences in the Quantitative Model Findings on the Price, Investment and Quality Effects of European 4-To-3 Mergers
affiliations: Corvinus University of Budapest

detail.title: Identifying The Root Causes of Differences in the Quantitative Model Findings on the Price, Investment and Quality Effects of European 4-To-3 Mergers

publicationDetails.detailsText: ITS 33rd European Conference 2025 30th June – 1st July 2025, Edinburgh, UK

detail.abstract: The EU Digital Decade 2030 connectivity targets require operators to provide full populationbased fixed and mobile broadband coverage. While there is a consensus on the identified investment gap, the proposed solutions are diverging. To stimulate investment, operators advocate more cooperation (horizontal mergers) to improve economies of scale, while regulators advocate more competition to encourage investment. This paper attempts to promote one truth understanding of the impact of 4-to-3 (mobile) operator horizontal mergers on social welfare, bringing together the two current camps of promoters and detractors, even at the academic level of telecoms economics. The research question aims to identify the root causes of differences in consumer prices, operator investments and service quality-related assessments in EU 4-to-3 mergers, and to provide a synthesized understanding of these differences. The methodology of the paper starts with qualitative research on competition policy aspects and then, based on the snowballing method, provides a systematic literature review and critical assessment of academic papers and Difference-inDifferences (DiD) fixed-panel models. The hypothesis is that the differences in the findings of quantitative models may be rooted in a lack of relevant assumptions and proper data specifications. The novelty of this paper lies in its comparison of promoter and detractor quantitative models within a common analytical framework, which is further extended to include profitability and return on investment aspects in order to demonstrate operators' incentives in merger decisionmaking. The key-finding is that, while horizontal mergers generally constrain competition, in certain cases there is a positive relationship between cooperation and competition. In many other cases, regulatory remedies can bring the market closer to the social welfare optimum.

title: Cultural Adaptation and the Role of Human Resources in Improving the Efficiency of International Operational Costs
affiliations: Universitas Muhammadiyah Palopo

detail.title: Cultural Adaptation and the Role of Human Resources in Improving the Efficiency of International Operational Costs
detail.abstract: The development of globalization has led multinational companies to expand their business to different countries with different cultures. In this case, cultural adaptation is an important element that supports operational success and cost efficiency. This study aims to examine the influence of cultural adaptation and the strategic function of human resources on cost efficiency in international operations. In this study, a mixed method was used, namely a quantitative approach through questionnaires and a qualitative approach through in-depth interviews. The research sample consisted of 52 respondents from multinational companies operating in the Southeast Asian region. The findings of the study show that there is a significant relationship between cultural adaptation and operational cost efficiency, with an important contribution from the strategic role of human resources as intermediaries. Companies that carry out cross-cultural training, adjust recruitment policies, and improve intercultural communication have been successful in reducing internal conflicts, increasing productivity, and lowering operational costs. Regression analysis revealed that the variables of cultural adaptation and the role of human resources together explained 64.5% of the variation in cost efficiency. In-depth interviews also show that a planned culture adaptation strategy and the active involvement of human resources in bridging cultural differences can accelerate global team integration as well as improve organizational performance. This research makes a theoretical contribution to the development of the literature on international management and intercultural human resource management. From a practical point of view, these results can serve as a guide for multinational companies in designing cultural adaptation policies and sustainable human resource management strategies to support cost efficiency.

title: Unlocking the Innovation Code: Towards a Grand Unified Theory
affiliations: African Research Network (ARN)

detail.title: Unlocking the Innovation Code: Towards a Grand Unified Theory
detail.abstract:
Innovation has long been perceived as an economic, technological, or social phenomenon. However, emerging research across disciplines—from complexity science and artificial intelligence to evolutionary biology and metaphysics—suggests that innovation is not merely a contingent human endeavor but a fundamental principle governing transformation across all domains of existence (Arthur, 2009; Kauffman, 2019).

This book seeks to establish Innovationology as a scientific and philosophical discipline that reveals the Meta-Law of Innovation—a universal trajectory driven by intelligence, complexity, and systemic emergence. The central claim of this book is that all transformative processes—scientific revolutions, biological evolution, technological progress, civilizational shifts, and even spiritual enlightenment—follow deep, intelligible laws embedded in reality (Goertzel, 2022; Tegmark, 2017).

This work positions innovation not as a human construct but as a cosmic principle, with clear mathematical, cognitive, and metaphysical foundations. By integrating theoretical physics, artificial intelligence, evolutionary dynamics, cognitive science, philosophy of technology, and complexity theory, this book constructs the first Grand Unified Theory of Innovation, providing a predictive and explanatory model for how transformation occurs at all levels of existence.

title: Autonomous Vehicles and the City: A Symposium Developing Policies and Plans for Livability
affiliations: University of San Francisco - School of Management, California State Polytechnic University, San Luis Obispo, University of San Francisco - School of Management, University of San Francisco - University of San Francisco - School of Business and Management, Students and University of San Francisco

detail.title: Autonomous Vehicles and the City: A Symposium Developing Policies and Plans for Livability
detail.abstract: This report summarizes the outcomes of the “Autonomous Vehicles and the City” symposium held at the University of San Francisco in November 2017. Bringing together policymakers, urban planners, designers, technologists, and academics, the symposium explored the profound implications of autonomous vehicles (AVs) on urban form, equity, the environment, and public policy. Discussions centered on how AVs may reshape land use patterns, influence real estate values, and disrupt existing transportation systems, while also offering opportunities to improve safety, accessibility, and sustainability. Panelists examined AV impacts across three domains—design and land use, social and environmental equity, and economics and real estate—and offered actionable policy recommendations for cities to prepare for an autonomous future. The report emphasizes the urgency for proactive planning, including revising zoning codes, rethinking parking infrastructure, investing in equitable access, and adapting revenue models to reflect AV-induced shifts. The findings call for a strategic, values-driven approach to integrating AVs that ensures inclusive, livable, and resilient urban futures.

reference: Journal of Engineering Research and Sciences, volume 4, issue 7, 2025[10.55708/js0407001]
title: Cloud ERP vs. On-Premise QAD ERP: A Cost-Benefit Analysis for Mid-Sized Manufacturers
affiliations: Manipal Institute of Technology

detail.title: Cloud ERP vs. On-Premise QAD ERP: A Cost-Benefit Analysis for Mid-Sized Manufacturers

publicationDetails.detailsText: Journal of Engineering Research and Sciences, volume 4, issue 7, 2025[10.55708/js0407001]

detail.abstract: For mid-sized manufacturing firms, the Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) system plays a crucial role in streamlining operations and enabling strategic growth. Both adopting cloudbased ERP solutions and continuing to use On-Premise applications like QAD are important decisions as digital transformation increases. In this study, we conduct a retrospective case study of the costbenefit analysis of Implementing Cloud Vs On-Premise QAD from a mid-size manufacturing perspective. The analysis is conducted based on industry reports, vendor pricing models, and structured interviews with IT and finance professionals from 10 mid-sized manufacturing firms in various industries. Total cost of ownership (TCO), implementation timelines, scalability, integration capabilities, system reliability, and long-term Return On Investment (ROI) are evaluated. The results suggest that while On-Premise QAD provides more control and more customization, cloud ERP facilitates lower upfront capital expenditure, higher operational agility, and faster updates and integrations, at least for the cases covered. Cloud ERP solutions' TCO and ROI within the first five years are also lower than On-Premise solutions, especially those that are associated with rapid growth or having a lean IT shop. This suggests that cloud ERP is generally more cost-effective and more adaptable to those who are digitally mature, growing medium-sized manufacturers, and that On-Premise QAD may still suit companies with some unique regulatory or customization needs. This work devises actionable strategies for making ERP investment decisions in a highly competitive manufacturing environment.

title: Performance measurements of the international joint ventures in an emerging market
affiliations: Prairie View A&M University - College of Business

detail.title: Performance measurements of the international joint ventures in an emerging market

declarations.declarationOfInterest: Not applicable
declarations.ethicsApproval: Not applicable
declarations.funderStatement: Not applicable

detail.abstract:
This chapter identifies ten major internal and external factors that may affect the processes of measuring performance of international joint ventures (IJVs) by their parents. A parent is defined as the business unit that administers, including giving continuing resources and support, and formulates the strategies of the IJVs. The factors are generally divided into internal and external perspectives. The internal factors include agency, control, strategy, technology, and transaction costs, whereas the external elements include culture and society, economy and market size, government and politics, industrial structure, and resources.

Based on a series of semi-structured interviews with the CEOs and CFOs of five organizations with 3 from manufacturing and 2 from services, whose parents are based in Houston, Texas, and their IJVs in the People’s Republic of China, this chapter concludes that all the factors have impact, one way or another, on the performance of IJVs. Thus, it is essential that the parents consider these factors when evaluating and rewarding the IJVs. Further, the parents should assess the performance based on both the financial and non-financial returns of IJVs. Results of this finding have implications for the parents, IJVs, and stakeholders of the organizations.

title: The Ethics of Defunding the Police
affiliations: Pennsylvania State University and Pennsylvania State University

detail.title: The Ethics of Defunding the Police
detail.abstract: Calls to defund the police gained prominence with the Black Lives Matter (BLM) movement and take various forms. Depending on what will be defunded, the idea has attracted support from different parts of the political spectrum. The politicized nature of the debate often cuts short reflection on how best to assess proposals to defund the police. This article takes up that task. It begins by developing a typology of defund measures: abolitionist cuts, abolitionist reallocation, disaggregative cuts, and disaggregative reallocation. It then outlines a framework to evaluate policing and defund measures, drawing on criteria from the ethics of defensive force. Since policing relies on force, it faces a high justificatory bar and must satisfy the principles of just aim, proportionality, and necessity. The state should not fund unjustified forms of policing that violate those principles. Different violations, though, demand different policy responses.

title: Perceived Benefits of Adopting Artificial Intelligence Technologies in Purchasing Processes
affiliations: Audencia Business School, Audencia Business School and Audencia Business School

detail.title: Perceived Benefits of Adopting Artificial Intelligence Technologies in Purchasing Processes
detail.abstract: • Purpose: This paper examines the benefits of Artificial Intelligence technologies in purchasing processes. In particular, it investigates four different types of AI-based technologies and their impact on 9 typical purchasing processes. • Design/methodology/approach: Based on a survey of 50 purchasing professionals mostly at senior positions, we investigated four AI-based technologies and we test their respective impact on nine purchasing processes. We have completed this survey with a series of 8 interviews, to subject matter experts in the field of AI in purchasing, in order to increase the granularity of our findings. • Findings: We found out that the adoption of AI is perceived to have a strong impact only on specific activities of the purchasing process (spend analysis, data quality, contract management). Our findings highlighted also the weak perceived influence of AI-based technologies directly on cost savings and risks mitigation, if organization do not manage the implementation of these technologies properly. Finally, our respondents perceived that data quality is the main beneficiary of several AI technologies. These findings open large avenues for future research relatively to purchasing digital transformation and AI. • Originality: this paper is one of the first, not to say the first paper to investigate benefits of AI in purchasing, building on a deductive approach. • Research limitations/implications: This paper extends research on purchasing digital transformation by shifting from the focus on technology-centric outcomes, such as information system usage, to understanding the outcomes of AI on purchasing process. The main limitation comes from the limited dataset (N=50) but we overcame this constraint through the usage of interviews to increase findings granularity. • Practical implications: Our paper suggests that purchasing managers should not only consider AI-based technologies as an important technological artifact, but also view it as a key driver of functional and strategic efficiency. It highlights also the limitations of several AI-based technologies, in respect of specific purchasing processes.

detail.abstract: In demographically diverse organizations, employees charged with socializing otherssocialization agents-must navigate a deep tension between the organization's needs to integrate individuals into a collective and individuals' needs for recognition of their unique identities. Through a qualitative study of employees in an urban charter high school where race and class inequalities are salient, we find that socialization agents experience this tension as identity threatening. We develop a theoretical model of relational reconciliation that traces how agents engage with this identity threat in an ongoing, stumbling process. Through relational reconciliation, agents come to redefine their selves in relation to their "socializees," which enables them to engage in elaborated socialization practices that aim to meet the needs of both the organization and the socializee. Our work repositions socialization agents as active parties in socialization, explores the tensions of socializing members of marginalized groups into a dominant culture, and reveals the importance of engaging with one's own identities to reconcile these tensions.

title: Real-Time Project Tracking Through Adaptive AI Monitoring Tools
affiliations: Independent Researcher, Independent Researcher and Independent Researcher

detail.title: Real-Time Project Tracking Through Adaptive AI Monitoring Tools
detail.abstract: Since projects have become more complicated and there is a demand for faster progress, traditional tracking techniques struggle to provide up-to-date information and smart early advice. This study investigates the role of adaptive AI monitoring tools in real-time project tracking for industries such as IT services, construction, software development, healthcare, and eLearning. We used a combination of qualitative and quantitative methods to compare traditional systems with AI-enhanced tools such as Click Up AI, Jira ML Plugin, and Asana Predictive Model. Results show improvements in task completion time, milestone accuracy, resource usage, and response time to issues. AI tools demonstrated high prediction accuracy, with Click Up reaching 88.3% accuracy, significantly reducing wait times. Additionally, user satisfaction was higher, and participants felt more confident in decision-making. Adaptive AI ensures real-time project views, dynamic risk management, and data driven decision-making. Future studies should focus on evaluating AI's long-term performance across various industries.

title: The Effect of Operation Management (OM) in Vocational Education and Training (VET) On Shaping Skilled Technicians: A Case Study of Elsewedy Technical Academy

detail.title: The Effect of Operation Management (OM) in Vocational Education and Training (VET) On Shaping Skilled Technicians: A Case Study of Elsewedy Technical Academy
detail.abstract: Overview of the skills gap issue: The mismatch between graduate skills and industry needs presents a formidable challenge to economic growth and innovation. Introduction to Elsewedy Technical Academy (STA) and its approach: This paper delves into the effect of private sector involvement in vocational education and training (VET), using the Elsewedy Technical Academy (STA) as a case study. STA, established by the Egyptian industrial giant Elsewedy, confronts the skills gap in its core sectors—electrical, construction, and renewable energy—through an innovative curriculum grounded in Operation Management (OM) principles. Summary of research objectives and methods: The research employs a mixed-methods approach, including document analysis, interviews, and site visits, to explore STA's curriculum development. It assesses how the academy's OM-driven curriculum not only aligns with industry needs but also integrates practical training and soft skills development, thereby fostering strong industry-academia collaboration. Key findings on the effectiveness of STA's OM-driven curriculum: Preliminary findings suggest that STA's approach effectively equips graduates with relevant skills, significantly enhancing their employability. Implications for the broader field of VET: This paper argues that STA's model can serve as a blueprint for industry-aligned VET, with potential implications for policy and practice in developing skilled technicians to meet the demands of modern industries.

title: Cultural Analysis of the Legend of Guando
affiliations: EDUKIVOTOS

detail.title: Cultural Analysis of the Legend of Guando
detail.abstract: This academic work offers a multidimensional analysis of the Colombian legend El Guando, exploring its ritual, emotional, aesthetic, pedagogical, economic, and narrative dimensions. Grounded in theories from Jung, Plutchik, Eliade, Turner, and Bourdieu, the study reveals how this myth acts as a symbolic regulator, emotional archetype, and potential driver of local cultural tourism. It rescues the legend from marginalization, reinterpreting it as a living element of intangible heritage with contemporary social, psychological, and economic relevance. The research emphasizes its adaptability and value in sustainable development and collective memory.

title: Scheduling Lunar Satellite Communications with Risk of Data Interception
affiliations: State University of New York (SUNY) - University at Buffalo, University at Buffalo, University at Buffalo, University at Buffalo and State University of New York (SUNY) - University at Buffalo

detail.title: Scheduling Lunar Satellite Communications with Risk of Data Interception
detail.abstract: This paper considers the scheduling of communication jobs from Moon ground stations to Earth via satellites in cislunar orbit, while limiting the risk of data interception. When a Moon ground station is transmitting to its target satellite, the transmission can be intercepted by another satellite in the vicinity. The risk of data interception should be limited for the goal of secure communications. A mixed integer linear program is formulated to maximize the reward from job data transmitted to Earth. The model is formulated to allow re-optimization at the next resolve period with remaining jobs in the system and the addition of new jobs. A heuristic using the linear program portion of the model and a job rank order allocation procedure is proposed. A schedule compression procedure is also proposed for the case without reward decay. Numerical experiments with and without reward decay are performed to evaluate the heuristic and to examine the impacts of increasing ground stations, satellites and satellite receive rate capacity.

detail.title: Cultural Analysis of the Legend of the Alligator Man
detail.abstract:
This academic work explores the multifaceted dimensions of the Colombian legend El Hombre Caimán, analyzing its social, ethical, emotional, territorial, and economic functions. Through interdisciplinary lenses—myth theory, semiotics, pedagogy, cultural transmission, and symbolic economy—the study examines how the legend adapts across generations, media formats, and cultural contexts. It highlights the role of the myth in community identity, emotional processing, moral teaching, and cultural tourism, while critically reflecting on the risks of commodification.

title: Assessing Legal Enforcement in India: A Comparative Analysis of Tamil Nadu and the National Average using the Legal Enforcement Index (LEI) 2025
affiliations: Central University of Jammu

detail.title: Assessing Legal Enforcement in India: A Comparative Analysis of Tamil Nadu and the National Average using the Legal Enforcement Index (LEI) 2025
detail.abstract: The efficacy of a state's legal enforcement machinery is a cornerstone of the rule of law and a critical determinant of socioeconomic progress. This paper introduces the Legal Enforcement Index (LEI), a composite metric designed to assess the capacity and performance of justice delivery systems in India. Using data primarily from the India Justice Report (IJR) 2025, we construct the LEI based on six pillars: Police, Judiciary, Prisons, Legal Aid, Human Rights, and Anti-corruption. Our analysis reveals that Tamil Nadu's LEI for 2025 is 56.2, surpassing the estimated national average LEI of 52.4. The results indicate Tamil Nadu's relative strengths in prison management and judicial infrastructure, while also highlighting systemic national challenges such as workforce vacancies and prison overcrowding. The paper discusses the policy implications of these findings, addresses the methodological limitations stemming from data gaps in certain pillars, and proposes the use of regression analysis for future refinements of the index to ensure its empirical validity and robustness.

title: Unveiling the Hidden Value of Risks in Platform Finance
affiliations: Beijing Jiaotong University, Central University of Finance and Economics and California State University

detail.title: Unveiling the Hidden Value of Risks in Platform Finance
detail.abstract: Platform finance has emerged as a transformative innovation in supply chain finance, enabling capital-constrained suppliers to access liquidity while enhancing cash flow and operational flexibility for platforms. However, the impact of demand uncertainty and financial risk on platform finance decisions remains underexplored. This study makes a key contribution by reframing demand uncertainty and risk as strategic levers rather than threats, providing a nuanced understanding of their dual roles in platform finance. By integrating operational and financial risk perspectives, this research fills a gap in the literature and offers a comprehensive framework for risk-informed financing decisions. This paper develops a game-theoretic model to analyze a platform offering two common financing schemes-credit financing and factoring finance-and a capital-constrained supplier, focusing on unveiling the hidden value of risk, namely, how different risk levels affect the platform's and supplier's operational and financial decisions. Our findings challenge the traditional view that operational and financial risks are purely negative and demonstrate these risks' hidden value. We find that platform finance not only alleviates liquidity constraints but also enhances profitability for both platforms and suppliers. Counterintuitively, low levels of both risks hinder Pareto improvements, while high operational risk can foster joint profit gains. Furthermore, increased demand uncertainty, often regarded as a threat, can improve profitability when financial risk is appropriately managed. Credit financing and factoring finance yield distinct profit outcomes depending on the platform's role as a reseller or marketplace and the financial risk level. Our findings provide actionable guidance for platforms and capital-constrained suppliers to optimize financing strategies, demonstrating that effectively leveraging demand uncertainty and risks can unlock profitability and drive sustainable competitive advantage in platform-based ecosystems.
